message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Dynamic Event-Triggered Distributed Coordination Control and its Applications: A Survey of Trends and Techniques
Paper Abstract: Distributed coordination control is the current trend in networked systems and finds prosperous applications across a variety of fields, such as smart grids and intelligent transportation systems. One fundamental issue in coordinating and controlling a large group of distributed and networked agents is the influence of intermittent interagent interactions caused by constrained communication resources. Event-triggered communication scheduling stands out as a promising enabler to strike a balance between the desired control performance and the satisfactory resource efficiency. What distinguishes dynamic event-triggered scheduling from traditional static event-triggered scheduling is that the triggering mechanism can be dynamically adjusted over time in accordance with both available system information and additional dynamic variables. This article provides an up-to-date overview of dynamic event-triggered distributed coordination control. The motivation of dynamic event-triggered scheduling is first introduced in the context of distributed coordination control. Then some techniques of dynamic event-triggered distributed coordination control are discussed in detail. Implementation and design issues are well addressed. Furthermore, this article exemplifies two applications of dynamic event-triggered distributed coordination control in the fields of microgrids and automated vehicles. Several challenges are suggested to direct the future research.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

However, one notable result mentions Maurice Heemels was named Fellow of the IEEE in 2016 for contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems, indicating that event-triggered control is indeed a recognized research area in control systems.

However, the search results don't contain detailed technical definitions of this specific control methodology. For more in-depth technical information, you may want to search for academic publications or research papers on event-triggered control systems specifically.

I've completed the web search for "intelligent transportation systems." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

An intelligent transportation system (ITS) is an advanced application that aims to provide services relating to different modes of transport and traffic management and enable users to be better informed and make safer, more coordinated, and 'smarter' use of transport networks.

## Core Technologies

Intelligent transport systems incorporate a wide range of technologies, from basic management systems such as car navigation, traffic signal control, and variable-message signs, to more advanced, interconnected applications.

Key categories include:
- Telematics systems with GPS devices
- Monitoring and enforcement systems like automatic number plate recognition and speed cameras
- Parking guidance and information systems and Road Weather Information Systems

## Advanced Applications

A major application is providing real-time information to passengers, such as predicting the arrival time of public transport, achieved by processing data collected from transit vehicles with telematics and GPS tracking units.(no content)Data is shared through vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) and vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) communication, allowing for real-time hazard warnings and coordinated traffic flow, enhancing safety and efficiency.

## Global Organizations

The Intelligent Transportation Society of America (ITS America) is a Washington, D.C.-based membership and advocacy group for the development and deployment of intelligent transportation systems (ITS) in the United States.

Here's a comprehensive overview of smart grids based on the search results:

## Definition

The smart grid is an enhancement of the 20th century electrical grid, using two-way communications and distributed so-called intelligent devices.(no content)The term smart grid is most commonly defined as an electric grid that has been digitized to enable two way communication between producers and consumers.

## Key Features and Components

Research is mainly focused on three systems of a smart grid  the infrastructure system, the management system, and the protection system.(no content)A smart grid includes a variety of operation and energy measures: Advanced metering infrastructure, smart distribution boards and circuit breakers integrated with home control and demand response, load control switches and smart appliances, and renewable energy resources, including the capacity to charge parked electric vehicle batteries or larger arrays of batteries recycled from these.

## Benefits

The potential benefits from a smart grid include increased reliability, more efficient electricity use, better economics, and improved sustainability.(no content)The improved flexibility of the smart grid permits greater penetration of highly variable renewable energy sources such as solar power and wind power.

## Global Development

The concept of a smart grid began to emerge in the early 2000s. Since then, many countries have been pursuing a smart grid.(no content)In the 21st century, some developing countries like China, India, and Brazil were seen as pioneers of smart grid deployment.

Links: [{"title":"Self-driving car - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-driving_car"},{"title":"List of predictions for autonomous Tesla vehicles by Elon Musk - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_predictions_for_autonomous_Tesla_vehicles_by_Elon_Musk"},{"title":"Vehicular automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicular_automation"},{"title":"Cruise (autonomous vehicle) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cruise_(autonomous_vehicle)"},{"title":"Autonomous underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_underwater_vehicle"},{"title":"Regulation of self-driving cars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulation_of_self-driving_cars"},{"title":"Waymo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waymo"},{"title":"Zoox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoox"},{"title":"Internet of vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_of_vehicles"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned surface vehicles of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_surface_vehicles_of_the_United_States"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of autonomous vehicles:

## Definition and Overview

A self-driving car, also known as an autonomous car, driverless car, robotic car or robo-car, is a car that is capable of operating with reduced or no human input.(no content)They are sometimes called robotaxis, though this term refers specifically to self-driving cars operated for a ridesharing company.

## Levels of Autonomy

The Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) classifies road vehicle autonomy in six levels: Level 1 involves driver assistance where the vehicle controls steering or speed autonomously in specific circumstances; Level 2 involves partial automation with the vehicle controlling both steering and speed autonomously in specific circumstances; Level 3 involves conditional automation where the vehicle controls steering and speed under normal conditions but requires the driver to be ready to take control; Level 4 involves high automation where the vehicle travels autonomously under normal conditions without requiring driver oversight; and Level 5 involves full autonomy where the vehicle can complete travel autonomously in any environmental conditions.

## Current Commercial Services

Waymo operates commercial robotaxi services available to the public in Phoenix, the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, Atlanta, and Austin.(no content)As of December 2025, Waymo is offering 450,000 paid rides per week.(no content)Zoox officially began its robotaxi service in Las Vegas and launched its robotaxi service to the public in San Francisco, marking significant progress in commercial autonomous vehicle operations.

## Regulation

Multiple countries have passed local legislation and agreed on standards for the introduction of autonomous cars.

Web search results for query: "distributed control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Distributed control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_control_system"},{"title":"Distributed version control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_version_control"},{"title":"Category:Distributed version control systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Distributed_version_control_systems"},{"title":"Distributed parameter system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_parameter_system"},{"title":"Talk:Distributed control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Distributed_control_system"},{"title":"Decentralised system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralised_system"},{"title":"Hierarchical control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_control_system"},{"title":"Asynchronous system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asynchronous_system"},{"title":"Multi-room audio - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-room_audio"},{"title":"Revision Control System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Revision_Control_System"}]

Here are the search results for distributed control systems:

## Overview

A distributed control system (DCS) is a computerized control system for a process or plant usually with many control loops, in which autonomous controllers are distributed throughout the system, but there is no central operator supervisory control.

## Key Characteristics

The key attribute of a DCS is its reliability due to the distribution of the control processing around nodes in the system. This mitigates a single processor failure. If a processor fails, it will only affect one section of the plant process, as opposed to a failure of a central computer which would affect the whole process.(no content)This distribution of computing power local to the field Input/Output (I/O) connection racks also ensures fast controller processing times by removing possible network and central processing delays.

## Applications

DCS tends to be used on large continuous process plants where high reliability and security is important, and the control room is not necessarily geographically remote.

## System Architecture

Level 0 contains the field devices such as flow and temperature sensors, and final control elements, such as control valves. Level 1 contains the industrialised Input/Output (I/O) modules, and their associated distributed electronic processors. Level 2 contains the supervisory computers, which collect information from processor nodes on the system, and provide the operator control screens. Level 3 is the production control level, which does not directly control the process, but is concerned with monitoring production and monitoring targets. Level 4 is the production scheduling level.

## Modern Features

Modern DCS systems can also support fieldbus digital protocols, such as Foundation Fieldbus, profibus, HART, modbus, PC Link, etc. Modern DCSs also support neural networks and fuzzy logic applications.

I found comprehensive information about multi-agent systems control. Here are the key results:

## Definition and Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)The study of multi-agent systems is "concerned with the development and analysis of sophisticated AI problem-solving and control architectures for both single-agent and multiple-agent systems."

## Key Capabilities

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation as well as self-direction and other control paradigms and related complex behaviors.

## Consensus Control

An important aspect of multi-agent control is consensus dynamics. Consensus dynamics studies how a group of agentssuch as robots, sensors, or decision-makersinteracting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange, with the goal of ensuring that all agents eventually agree on a certain quantity.

## Applications

Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.(no content)Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

I found comprehensive information about multi-agent systems control. Here are the key results:

## Definition and Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)The study of multi-agent systems is "concerned with the development and analysis of sophisticated AI problem-solving and control architectures for both single-agent and multiple-agent systems."

## Key Capabilities

Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.(no content)Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation as well as self-direction and other control paradigms and related complex behaviors.

## Consensus Control

An important aspect of multi-agent control is consensus dynamics. Consensus dynamics studies how a group of agentssuch as robots, sensors, or decision-makersinteracting over a network can reach a common decision or estimate through local rules and information exchange, with the goal of ensuring that all agents eventually agree on a certain quantity.

## Applications

Consensus dynamics has applications in areas such as physiological systems, gene regulatory networks, large-scale energy systems, and coordinated control of autonomous vehicle fleets on land, in the air, or in space.(no content)Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

Web search results for query: "networked control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Networked control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Networked_control_system"},{"title":"HVAC control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HVAC_control_system"},{"title":"Systems integrator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_integrator"},{"title":"Concurrent Versions System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concurrent_Versions_System"},{"title":"Emilia Fridman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emilia_Fridman"},{"title":"QLab - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qlab"},{"title":"Roberto Tempo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Tempo"},{"title":"Direct digital control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_digital_control"},{"title":"Resilient control systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resilient_control_systems"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about networked control systems:

## Overview

A networked control system (NCS) is a control system wherein the control loops are closed through a communication network.(no content)The defining feature of an NCS is that control and feedback signals are exchanged among the system's components in the form of information packages through a network.

## Key Characteristics

The insertion of the communication network in the feedback control loop makes the analysis and design of an NCS complex, since it imposes additional time delays in control loops or possibility of packages loss.

## Network Types

Networked control systems can utilize various types of networks, including wired and wireless options. Wireless networks such as Bluetooth, Zigbee, and Z-Wave are common examples, with the term "wireless networked control system (WNCS)" often used in this context.

## Research Topics

New control strategies, kinematics of the actuators in the systems, reliability and security of communications, bandwidth allocation, development of data communication protocols, corresponding fault detection and fault tolerant control strategies, real-time information collection and efficient processing of sensors data are some of the relative topics studied in depth.

## Applications

Networked control systems have applications across various industrial domains, including HVAC systems, building automation, and critical infrastructure control.

Web search results for query: "consensus algorithms distributed systems"

Links: [{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Paxos (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxos_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Raft (algorithm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raft_(algorithm)"},{"title":"Distributed algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_algorithm"},{"title":"Category:Distributed algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Distributed_algorithms"},{"title":"Consensus dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_dynamics"},{"title":"Distributed ledger - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_ledger"},{"title":"TLA+ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TLA+"},{"title":"Distributed computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_computing"},{"title":"Consensus clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_clustering"}]

I've completed the web search for "consensus algorithms distributed systems." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

A fundamental problem in distributed computing is achieving overall system reliability in the presence of faulty processes, which often requires coordinating processes to reach consensus, or agree on some data value that is needed during computation.

## Major Consensus Algorithms

The Paxos consensus algorithm by Leslie Lamport, and variants of it such as Raft, are used pervasively in widely deployed distributed and cloud computing systems.

**Paxos:** Consensus protocols are the basis for the state machine replication approach to distributed computing, as suggested by Leslie Lamport, and state machine replication is a technique for converting an algorithm into a fault-tolerant, distributed implementation.(no content)These algorithms are typically synchronous, dependent on an elected leader to make progress, and tolerate only crashes and not Byzantine failures.

**Raft:** Raft is a consensus algorithm designed as an alternative to the Paxos family of algorithms, and was meant to be more understandable than Paxos by means of separation of logic, but it is also formally proven safe and offers some additional features.(no content)Raft offers a generic way to distribute a state machine across a cluster of computing systems, ensuring that each node in the cluster agrees upon the same series of state transitions.

## Real-World Applications

Example applications of consensus include agreeing on what transactions to commit to a database in which order, state machine replication, and atomic broadcasts, and real-world applications often requiring consensus include cloud computing, clock synchronization, PageRank, opinion formation, smart power grids, state estimation, control of UAVs, load balancing, blockchain, and others.

Links: [{"title":"Microgrid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microgrid"},{"title":"Husk Power Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Husk_Power_Systems"},{"title":"Electrical grid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electrical_grid"},{"title":"Living Energy Farm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Living_Energy_Farm"},{"title":"Reza Iravani - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reza_Iravani"},{"title":"Power engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_engineering"},{"title":"Distributed generation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_generation"},{"title":"Smart grid - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smart_grid"},{"title":"Power system reliability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_system_reliability"},{"title":"Energy in Western Australia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_in_Western_Australia"}]

## Microgrid Power Systems

Based on the search results, here's an overview of microgrid power systems:

### Definition
A microgrid is a group of interconnected loads and distributed energy resources with defined electrical boundaries, which form a local electric power system at distribution voltage levels, meaning both low and medium voltage up to 35 kV.(no content)The U.S. Department of Energy defines a microgrid as a group of interconnected loads and distributed energy resources within clearly defined electrical boundaries that acts as a single controllable entity with respect to the grid, and can connect and disconnect from the grid to enable it to operate in both grid-connected or island-mode.

### Key Components
Microgrids comprise low-voltage distribution systems with distributed energy resources such as microturbines, fuel cells, and photovoltaics, as well as storage devices like batteries and flywheels.(no content)Microgrid generation resources can include stationary batteries, fuel cells, solar, wind, or other energy sources.

### Types and Applications
Stand-alone microgrids have their own sources of electricity supplemented with energy storage systems and are used where power transmission and distribution from a major centralized energy source is too far and costly to operate, offering an option for rural electrification in remote areas and on smaller geographical islands.(no content)Microgrids are self-sufficient energy systems that serve a discrete geographic footprint, such as a college campus, hospital complex, business center or neighborhood.

### Benefits
Compared to larger grids, microgrids typically use a lower voltage distribution network and distributed generators, and may not only be more resilient, but may be cheaper to implement in isolated areas.(no content)Microgrids, which can operate both connected to and independent from the main grid, offer resilience by supplying critical loads during main grid outages.

## Microgrid Power Systems

Based on the search results, here's an overview of microgrid power systems:

### Definition
A microgrid is a group of interconnected loads and distributed energy resources with defined electrical boundaries, which form a local electric power system at distribution voltage levels, meaning both low and medium voltage up to 35 kV.(no content)The U.S. Department of Energy defines a microgrid as a group of interconnected loads and distributed energy resources within clearly defined electrical boundaries that acts as a single controllable entity with respect to the grid, and can connect and disconnect from the grid to enable it to operate in both grid-connected or island-mode.

### Key Components
Microgrids comprise low-voltage distribution systems with distributed energy resources such as microturbines, fuel cells, and photovoltaics, as well as storage devices like batteries and flywheels.(no content)Microgrid generation resources can include stationary batteries, fuel cells, solar, wind, or other energy sources.

### Types and Applications
Stand-alone microgrids have their own sources of electricity supplemented with energy storage systems and are used where power transmission and distribution from a major centralized energy source is too far and costly to operate, offering an option for rural electrification in remote areas and on smaller geographical islands.(no content)Microgrids are self-sufficient energy systems that serve a discrete geographic footprint, such as a college campus, hospital complex, business center or neighborhood.

### Benefits
Compared to larger grids, microgrids typically use a lower voltage distribution network and distributed generators, and may not only be more resilient, but may be cheaper to implement in isolated areas.(no content)Microgrids, which can operate both connected to and independent from the main grid, offer resilience by supplying critical loads during main grid outages.

}
EOF
